content:
Posted: April 16, 2016
												For fans of stereoscopic 3D gaming, this game is a must-buy.  There are many games which look fantastic in Nvidia 3d Vision, but the Trine games (especially 2 and 3) are so good as to be useful for modeling the technology, in my opinion.  Furthermore, unlike many games that work well in 3D Vision and nothing else, the Trine games have additional 3D modes to make the game compatible with pretty much any stereoscopic setup you have.  If you have a modern 3D TV and choose to play this game in 2D, you are doing yourself a serious disservice.  Get an extra-long hdmi cable, if you have to, and attach your computer to your TV!  (Or invest in a 3D Vision setup, if you are a fan of stereoscopic 3D movies and games.)The game is oodles of fun with a friend, in both local and internet co-op, with the difference being that the two characters must share a screen for local co-op; netplay has no such limitation, and you can get separated if you are not careful.  That said, I recommend the latter for those who have both options available to then.Sadly, the game has its share of internet MP bugginess, worse than the first game did (but not as bad as the third).  It was so bad that my friend and I (with him in America and me in Japan, both of us with excellent internet connections) were not able to complete the DLC's final boss, which is arguably broken for multiplayer (possibly local MP as well, given the way the boss spazzes out and gets confused when more than one target is available).  So while I must shake my finger at Frozenbyte for not play-testing and bug-proofing the multiplayer more, I cannot in good conscious give this anything other than a thumbs-up, for its combination of appealing platforming, charming characters and voice acting, and jaw-droppingly gorgeous visuals, which really must be viewed in stereoscopic 3D to be fully appreciated.Artistic Value: 9.5Fun Factor: 8 (probably lower while playing solo and/or in 2D)My Score: 8.5

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 16
												WOW! What an improvement over the first one!Mostly pros and a few cons.Pros:- The first game was stunning and this just blew me away with how much it improved over the first game - It has better puzzles- More level traversing mechanics that work REALLY well- More character skills that are easier to execute- No mana (this was mostly superfluous in the first game)- Enemy battles are more engaging- Much more fluid controls  > Using the Rogue's grappling hook to get on to a platform from underneath is much easier > The ability for my character to make it onto a platform with a jump is much more lenient > Easier to summon and destroy things with the Wizard (quick squiggle = box, botched line = plank (yay) instead of box (boo), which was frustrating from the first game)- I can read the narration and skip faster to get into the level as a resultCons:- The only thing they haven't improved from the first game is that the Rogue needs a grappling hook aim when using a controller as she often latches onto the wrong platform or the wrong part of a platform. The grappling hook should also be able to retract further making it as easy as it should be to get on to platforms (despite that they somewhat improved this from the first game).- Things that are CLEARLY made of wood can't be grappled on to- Spiders sometimes spawn camp and this can become a little annoying- The camera is appalling in so many instances (normally too zoomed in) and it would be far better with a player controlled zoom function!

I can really recommend this game to both casual and hardcore gamers.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 16, 2014
												The second installment of trinity: galactic expedia unleashed, breaks new ground in the gaming landscape. Trinity, or Trin for short is a tale about Duncon Stone, a recently rehabilitated drug addict recovering from severe trauma at an asylum in baltimore. Duncon, or dunk as the inmates call him was a former software engineer for microsoft but after raising a mutiny against steve jobs he was publically executed on the streets of johanesberg where he worked. What they didnt expect was that his corpse was exported to colombo where the doctors worked on him. they utilised various new implants and turned him into a man like machine called the Trine. Trine is a code name for the project, Transplant Ressurected infantry of new Eden. New eden is a bioengineering cartel that spans oceanic borders that funnels billions of dollars worth of biotechnology and unlicensed equipment into key geographic areas. The TRINE project is an attempt to create a global po-lice force designed to implement a new regime once individual governments topple following an expected economic collapse post global financial fiasco. As a Trine unit you are subordinate to your task master, some inglorious ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ who goes by the name of "the cammel's muel".  CM is what the guys in the lab call him, but to Duncan stone he is the epicentre of a world of suffering under his rule. CM send you all over the globe doing secret missions to merge and consolidate important equipment under his roof. On one uneventful escort mission to secure a new type of balistics device, Duncon gets hit by the typical natural disarster employed in all games these days, you guessed it.. lightaning!. that's right, he takes a bolt to the head which fries the inhibitor chip that CM daddy uses to control him. But the other players know this. and they're coming for you. The game then turns into its multiplayer feature here, which is essentially a treadmil of experiance grinding in order to gear up for the boss fight back in the New eden facility. Its very uninspired and doesent add much to whats already out there in terms of Trinity's mian competitors, namely farming simulator 2000 and football manager 2014. In any case you get some cool guns and the matchmaking system is okay. Once youre geared up you get to face off against the cammels muel in an all star battle of the ages. We're back to single player here now guys just for the record. after a grindy battle of tearing down his health and toking up on heal potions through the entire fight you eventually kill him. Unfortunately for stone, the facility does actually explode trapping him in the compartment underneath. THe game ends with duncon stone putting himself into cryosleep since he is faced with no other alternitive. This sory arc therefore is the prequel of Demolition Man, which aired in the 80's. Overall, not a bad film. Demolition man had some cool plot twists and the actor played the part well. 4/10 in terms of special effects, the 80's dont really compare to where we are today. Either way, if youre keep to tune into some good old fashioned film, Demolition man is the way to go.Until next time, stay snazzy!

content:
Posted: December 23, 2013
												Trine 2 is a gorgeous problem-solving game that I missed out on for way too long.  It has challenges requiring the use of multiple characters that will remind any SNES fan of The Lost Vikings, but with graphics to match the modern day.  Interestingly, most problems have multiple solutions, even allowing you to use just 1 of the 3 characters to get through whole stages.  On top of that, it has a very forgiving default difficulty in case you're more interested in the puzzles than the adventure game aspects.  By and large, a relaxing game, well worth the time and price.

content:
Posted: June 25, 2014
												Trine 2 is a gorgeous physics-based 3D platformer, and it’s meant to be experienced with friends. The most important difference from the original Trine is that this game supports three-player co-op over the internet. It may seem like a "well, duh" feature, but it makes a world of difference over the previous local-only game.By building on its successes rather than messing with its entertaining gameplay, Trine 2's simple concept of trekking toward the right side of the screen feels more like an otherworldly adventure than just another platformer. The abilities of your three playable characters - Wizard, Rogue, and Warrior - synergize superbly. Though at times you may feel overly dependent on another character's unique skills, the often misplaced trust you put in your friends’ talent will generally lead to hilarious and unintended successes. Frequently, the way to figure out a puzzle is to throw yourself at it until you discover a solution. A side-effect of this is death, but thankfully, it’s hardly a penalty. As long as one character remains alive and makes it to one of the many checkpoints in a level, the others are instantly revived. If everybody dies, all progress is saved and everybody is reincarnated at the latest checkpoint. This serves the flow of the game well, because your sense of adventure is never punished; indeed, being practically immortal in a platformer is surprisingly fun!Don’t expect much from the story; other than giving a reason to run to the right, it exists only to provide context to Trine 2’s challenges and puzzles. The reward for figuring out each scenario is mainly a sense of progression – but it works. Progression could mean accumulating experience potions that grant each character improved skills or new abilities, or it could mean discovering hard-to-reach chests that contain pieces of concept art or a narrated stanza from the main antagonist’s journal. Simply getting to the next level is often reward enough, because this game’s vibrant visuals are stunning.Trine 2's artistic merit is absolutely jaw-dropping. The title screen alone sets the bar for the rest of the game. (Try starting the game at different times during the day!) Half of my play-time was spent taking in the stunningly beautiful backdrops and set pieces. I felt guilty when I solved a puzzle without fully admiring the obscene amount of effort put into the graphical presentation of this game. The quality is consistently superb - worthy of your attention all the way through to the last chapter - and every shade of the rainbow gets a feature performance. The fun to be had in applying home-brewed solutions to solving puzzles with your friends is what sustains Trine 2 until its end. Along with constantly being rewarded with beautiful vistas and remarkably decorated interiors, finding all the hidden goodies will definitely tempt your inner completionist. Although you may need to set personal goals to warrant a second play-through, Trine 2 is a very entertaining game to play over a week with one or two of your friends.

content:
Posted: August 11, 2016
												Trine 2 is a side-scrolling action platform/puzzle game developed by Frozenbyte. And obviously, it is the sequel to Trine.The game improves everything from the original by adding more fun to play abilities, such as Monster Levitation(grab and levitate monsters), Monster Prison(catch enemies in boxes) and Metal Magnetizing(conjured objects can be magnetized) for the Wizard, there is also Frost/Fire/Explosive Arrows, Stealth Movement and Low Gravity Field for the Thief, and lastly there is Frost Shield, Fire Sword, Hammer Throwing/Explosion, Charge and Magnetic Shield for the Knight.Besides the gameplay improvements, the game is even move beautiful than the original Trine (#1, #2, #3) and the soundtrack is even more impressive.For me, Trine 2 is the best of the series. It provides a lot of new great content that offers hours upon hours of fun in local/online co-op with friends or solo.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 20, 2015
												Trine 2: Complete Story is an hybrid between a platform and puzzle game developed by developer Froze Byte and follows the adventure of three heroes, Amadeus the Magnificent, Zoya and Pontius the Brave, as they are guided by a mysterious magical entity, the titular Trine, to face a dark plot involving their kingdom. The Complet Story edition adds to the original some tweaks and include the only major DLC for the game, Goblin Menace, for free.The main beef of Trine 2 is about using the unique perks and abilities of each character or combine them as needed in order to advance in the levels you are thrown in: while there are some enemy encounters through the game, they are a rarity and are easily overcame with the trio's basic abilities (even the few bosses featured are pretty straightforward, save for the final bosses, who are more puzzle game fare in nature). Amadeus the Magnificent doesn't have any combat abilities to speak of and is rather fragile, but can conjure crates or move elements of the scenery to help his comrades. Zoya, instead, is a classic rogue character: she can move faster and jump higher than the other two characters, use a grappling tool to swing around on wooden surfaces and damage enemies from afar using her bow and different kind of arrows. Finally, Portius the Brave is a very sturdy, shielded warrior who fills the role of the group's tank against enemies and heavy damage dealer: after unlocking some of his additional abilities, however, Portius also becomes useful during the platforming sections as a support character.The levels of Trine 2 feature several experience orbs you can collect to level up your characters: each level gained unlocks an ability point you can spend in the talent tree of each hero. Some of these unlocked abilities only enhance the skills the characters already posses, while others introduce totally new gimmicks capable of making the later section of the game much easier to handle.It can be argued that one of the main attraction in Trine 2 are its impressive visual, especially for being a side scroller game: all the characters and environments are rendered in great 3D detail and the scenaries are multiple layers to them. The art style also feels rather unique.One of the main novelty of Trine 2 in comparison to the original game are its only features: a party of three players can experience the whole adventure while playing together online, each controlling his/her own character. On top of being a rather entertaining experience, the multiplayer element also makes the game easier to handle and mixing the heroes' powers much more straightforward.Trine 2's replayability is a bit scarce: once you've been playing through the whole game and found a solution to all the puzzles and obstacles, the only real reason to come back for a second run is to play with your friends or change your default character. There are also collectables to be found inside the levels (pieces of poetry and paintings/concept art), but finding them isn't exactly a serious challenge.The Goblin Menace DLC is the only additional content released for Trine 2 and follows the story of Amadeus, Zoya and Portius after their great adventure as they try to save Amadeus' wife from an aggressive army of goblins. The DLC doesn't offer any new gameplay elements whatsoever, both in general mechanics and characters' abilities: on the other side, however, it lasts for some interesting hours, has its own story and, if possible, the level design is even more complex and gorgeous than the one from the main game.Trine 2: Complete Story is an entertaining game with its own peculiar identity and apparel that I found very enjoyable, moreso if taken on with a pair of friends along the way

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 15, 2016
												This is another begrudging approval. Trine 2 is not a bad game, but it's also not awesome. Most of it is, well, boring. Admittedly, that boringness is nicely polished.The first Trine had a neat gimmick in the ability to instantly switch between the three character classes, and the fact that you sometimes had to use this to solve puzzles. The problem is that Trine 2 doesn't really build on this in any meaningful way. It's just more of the same. Add to that the fact that the story is even less relevant to our characters this time around (they don't even know the people who the story revolves around) and it's hard to care about anything that happens.The combat requires no thought and you can generally brute force your way through without any problems. Even the boss fights can be bulldozed through with simple repetition. And once you put enough upgrades into the wizard the same can be said for the puzzles. That means that the early game and first few levels are significantly more challenging because you won't have those abilities yet. But put in a little time and thought and the game becomes a breeze.It looks very nice - they definitely upped the graphical fidelity this time around. It comes at a cost though. The first Trine ran just fine on my standard work laptop, while Trine 2 gets about one frame a second.There also seems to be less banter and fewer jokes between the characters this time around. It's still there a little bit, but it's disappointing there's not more because that was largely what made the first game so charming.If you absolutely loved the first Trine then it's probably worth a quick playthrough of the second. But while there are some nice cosmetics and a few hours of diverting gameplay, the series seems to have misplaced its soul.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 15, 2016
												This is another begrudging approval. Trine 2 is not a bad game, but it's also not awesome. Most of it is, well, boring. Admittedly, that boringness is nicely polished.The first Trine had a neat gimmick in the ability to instantly switch between the three character classes, and the fact that you sometimes had to use this to solve puzzles. The problem is that Trine 2 doesn't really build on this in any meaningful way. It's just more of the same. Add to that the fact that the story is even less relevant to our characters this time around (they don't even know the people who the story revolves around) and it's hard to care about anything that happens.The combat requires no thought and you can generally brute force your way through without any problems. Even the boss fights can be bulldozed through with simple repetition. And once you put enough upgrades into the wizard the same can be said for the puzzles. That means that the early game and first few levels are significantly more challenging because you won't have those abilities yet. But put in a little time and thought and the game becomes a breeze.It looks very nice - they definitely upped the graphical fidelity this time around. It comes at a cost though. The first Trine ran just fine on my standard work laptop, while Trine 2 gets about one frame a second.There also seems to be less banter and fewer jokes between the characters this time around. It's still there a little bit, but it's disappointing there's not more because that was largely what made the first game so charming.If you absolutely loved the first Trine then it's probably worth a quick playthrough of the second. But while there are some nice cosmetics and a few hours of diverting gameplay, the series seems to have misplaced its soul.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 20, 2015
												Trine 2: Complete Story is an hybrid between a platform and puzzle game developed by developer Froze Byte and follows the adventure of three heroes, Amadeus the Magnificent, Zoya and Pontius the Brave, as they are guided by a mysterious magical entity, the titular Trine, to face a dark plot involving their kingdom. The Complet Story edition adds to the original some tweaks and include the only major DLC for the game, Goblin Menace, for free.The main beef of Trine 2 is about using the unique perks and abilities of each character or combine them as needed in order to advance in the levels you are thrown in: while there are some enemy encounters through the game, they are a rarity and are easily overcame with the trio's basic abilities (even the few bosses featured are pretty straightforward, save for the final bosses, who are more puzzle game fare in nature). Amadeus the Magnificent doesn't have any combat abilities to speak of and is rather fragile, but can conjure crates or move elements of the scenery to help his comrades. Zoya, instead, is a classic rogue character: she can move faster and jump higher than the other two characters, use a grappling tool to swing around on wooden surfaces and damage enemies from afar using her bow and different kind of arrows. Finally, Portius the Brave is a very sturdy, shielded warrior who fills the role of the group's tank against enemies and heavy damage dealer: after unlocking some of his additional abilities, however, Portius also becomes useful during the platforming sections as a support character.The levels of Trine 2 feature several experience orbs you can collect to level up your characters: each level gained unlocks an ability point you can spend in the talent tree of each hero. Some of these unlocked abilities only enhance the skills the characters already posses, while others introduce totally new gimmicks capable of making the later section of the game much easier to handle.It can be argued that one of the main attraction in Trine 2 are its impressive visual, especially for being a side scroller game: all the characters and environments are rendered in great 3D detail and the scenaries are multiple layers to them. The art style also feels rather unique.One of the main novelty of Trine 2 in comparison to the original game are its only features: a party of three players can experience the whole adventure while playing together online, each controlling his/her own character. On top of being a rather entertaining experience, the multiplayer element also makes the game easier to handle and mixing the heroes' powers much more straightforward.Trine 2's replayability is a bit scarce: once you've been playing through the whole game and found a solution to all the puzzles and obstacles, the only real reason to come back for a second run is to play with your friends or change your default character. There are also collectables to be found inside the levels (pieces of poetry and paintings/concept art), but finding them isn't exactly a serious challenge.The Goblin Menace DLC is the only additional content released for Trine 2 and follows the story of Amadeus, Zoya and Portius after their great adventure as they try to save Amadeus' wife from an aggressive army of goblins. The DLC doesn't offer any new gameplay elements whatsoever, both in general mechanics and characters' abilities: on the other side, however, it lasts for some interesting hours, has its own story and, if possible, the level design is even more complex and gorgeous than the one from the main game.Trine 2: Complete Story is an entertaining game with its own peculiar identity and apparel that I found very enjoyable, moreso if taken on with a pair of friends along the way

content:
Posted: March 21, 2013
												The wonderful and ingenius second installment of what I think is the best physics based puzzle game franchise. This sequel offers a unique fairytale storybook style in contrast to the dark, somewhat dungeon based original. The game feels more open than its predecessor despite removing items and replacing them with sparce non-gameplay influencing collectibles. This game is packed with impressive, long levels and excellent replayability. Players have to be more creative and conservative as puzzle are not as easily circumvented though solving them is more interesting and visually rewarding. This game is well worth buying at a sale (about $5) and has an equally incredible expansion pack (about $2 on sale) that adds a new chapter to the story and plenty of new levels and skills to play with. I truly recommend fans of puzzle games and casual gamers to buy this game. Also, see my review of the original Trine.

content:
Posted: March 17, 2015
												Trine 2 is a gorgeous, fun game that I would wholeheartedly recommend, even though I am not someone who normally enjoys puzzle games. The world is vibrant and colorful, with great music and fun, if simple, characters to go along with it. It is a light-hearted, relaxing, fun game with a lot of charm. The puzzles were enjoyable. I had a good laugh with my co-op partner. We trolled each other and had quite a few memorable moments playing the game. I feel like the wizard was the most well-thought out character in the game and that the thief and knight didn't get quite as much attention as the wizard, but this is a very minor nitpick. Playing the thief and the knight wasn't a bore; I mostly played the thief during my playthrough and still had a great experience. The puzzles were creative, but not frustrating. I didn't feel that any of the puzzles were unfair. I found myself laughing at the silly mistakes we made more often than not.The balance between combat and puzzle sections leave no room for boredom. And the adjustable level of difficulty gives newcomers and veterans a fair chance to prove their abilities. Furthermore the multiplayer adds some extra life to the game, as the experience is genuinely different.The DLC in form of Goblin Menace adds a couple new levels, a new story, and several new skills which will also be available in the original game.Overall Trine 2 feels more refined than its predecessor and the beautiful artwork in combination with the creative puzzle sections are very persuasive and entertaining. In addition it offers enough content to justify itself as a worthy sequel to Trine.Fun fact: Due to relatively poor sales for Trine 2 on Xbox 360 and PlayStation 3, the conversion for the expansion for these consoles was deemed not be cost effective, thus Trine 2: Goblin Menace was never released for these platforms. The graphics are top notch with great lighting. The fluidity of the animation and controls are perfect so that while some of the puzzle sections may be difficult at times they are never blamed on the slick controls. The levels are long enough to be enjoyable and not too long where they get boring. Each level offers a variety of landscapes and scenery, all of which are beautiful. The storyline is forgettable, but still sets up a good reason for why you are playing the game. The three different characters offer very different ways of playing and each offer different ways to solve the puzzles. Think of it as an action only version of Quest for Glory where each character has a different solution to each puzzle. The addition of the Goblin Menace, the Dwarven Carverns and now the Workshop has helped expand and continue the gameplay of this fabulous series.Trine 2 takes everything that made Trine fun and improves on it. It has better combat, and more entertaining puzzels. The soundtrack is great, and the game looks visually gorgeous, I have got to say Trine 2 Really is pretty great overall, and it is still modable, so again, this is a great aspect to have if you are looking to get your moneys worth. I would reccomend Trine 2 to anyone looking for an Indie game, a Sidescroller, Puzzle, or artsy looking game. I have got to say there is a good ammount of fun to be had with Trine 2, so dont pass judgement too quickly.The mechanics of the game are a refinement and improvement over the original Trine, with you switching between heroes on the fly and using their respective strengths to fight and puzzle your way through various environments, however this time it feels much slicker, and much more confident in what it does, there's many points where you'll be scratching your head, only to have the light flick on with a genuine "AH HA!" moment. It's never punishingly difficult, but it's pleasantly challenging. The lack of gore and fantasy nature of the game makes it very family friendly too, older children will get a kick out of the fantasy setting, and adults will no doubt get many of the references. In this it resembles a Pixar film, a comparison I make very affectionately.Do please check this game out, it deserves your time and attention.

Posted: March 18, 2015
												The brilliant artistry, great soundtrack, and immersive real-time puzzles in this game are, if possible, even better than it's predecessor. Although Trine 2 features less RPG elements than Trine 1, the fun is none the less for it. In Trine 2, you play once again as Pontius the knight, Zoya the theif, and Amadeus the wizard, while battling new foes, using new abilities, and solving new puzzles, all in a thoroughly beautiful fairy tale world of action, myth and mystery.Once again, I recommend this installment of the Trine franchise to any and all gamers.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 17, 2015
												Where do I even BEGIN with this game?First, the gameplay. The puzzles in the game CAN be difficult at times, but they can be solved in many ways.Second, the story. What could be said that hasn't been said already about it? It has everything anyone could possibly want in a fairytale story: Three heroes on a quest,  majestic fantasy lands, and a villain the heroes must wage war on.Third, the characters. They all have their own personalities, strengths, and weaknesses. Amadeus is a wizard, so he can conjure boxes and planks and lift objects. Pontius is a knight, making him the go-to guy for battling enemies. And Zoya is a thief--whoops! I mean archer. She has a bow for ranged attacks, and uses a grappling hook to swing from point A to point B.Fourth, the music. I'm just gonna come out and say it; Ari Pulkkinen really outdid himself here. Such incredible melodies and crescendos make it all the more enjoyable. Listening to these compositions, you'd think these were actually covers for songs by Blackmore's Night!Fifth, the cast. The voice actors from the last game made it to the sequel. Namely, Kevin Howarth(Amadeus), Victoria Kruger(Zoya), and Brian Bowles(Pontius). But there are also two other voice actors that do a good job as their characters. Also, Terry Wilton(narrator), I love you, but you GOTTA stop milking your role here. You're just too good! You have a gift.Sixth, and most importantly, the presentation. When Frostbyte said they featured every color of the rainbow, they weren't kidding. In fact, I saw a couple of rainbows throughout the game! it all looks so bright and vivid like a fantasy world would normally look.So, that's all I gotta say. Check this game out for yourselves. You WON'T be disappointed.

content:
Posted: December 25, 2013
												Probably one of my favorite games. I'm really picky when it comes to games, but this one stands out to me. Ambition all around. Very detailed animations, great physics, controls are comfortable and it's just REALLY beautiful. Highly recommended to play in 3D if you can get your hands on it. But, it's probably less fun if you play it alone. Co-op it and you're going to be laughing a lot. Solo is alright too but it's really intended to be played together. But for the price, especially during sales it's worth it. (Still can't believe the price of this game actually drops to 1.50 during the sales, these devs deserve a lot more for this ambitious game.)Voice actors are silly, I find it pretty comedic. Story's easy to follow because they don't overwhelm you with a ton of hierarchies.

Posted: December 7, 2012
												I cannot recommend this game highly enough. Trine 2 is one of the best platformers I have ever played. The game gives you an unparalleled ability to experiment and solve navigation, combat and item collection puzzles in a multitude of ways. It also has a wonderful physics system, tight controls, great voice acting and it's also one gorgeous looking game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 21, 2013
												The wonderful and ingenius second installment of what I think is the best physics based puzzle game franchise. This sequel offers a unique fairytale storybook style in contrast to the dark, somewhat dungeon based original. The game feels more open than its predecessor despite removing items and replacing them with sparce non-gameplay influencing collectibles. This game is packed with impressive, long levels and excellent replayability. Players have to be more creative and conservative as puzzle are not as easily circumvented though solving them is more interesting and visually rewarding. This game is well worth buying at a sale (about $5) and has an equally incredible expansion pack (about $2 on sale) that adds a new chapter to the story and plenty of new levels and skills to play with. I truly recommend fans of puzzle games and casual gamers to buy this game. Also, see my review of the original Trine.

content:
Posted: December 25, 2013
												Probably one of my favorite games. I'm really picky when it comes to games, but this one stands out to me. Ambition all around. Very detailed animations, great physics, controls are comfortable and it's just REALLY beautiful. Highly recommended to play in 3D if you can get your hands on it. But, it's probably less fun if you play it alone. Co-op it and you're going to be laughing a lot. Solo is alright too but it's really intended to be played together. But for the price, especially during sales it's worth it. (Still can't believe the price of this game actually drops to 1.50 during the sales, these devs deserve a lot more for this ambitious game.)Voice actors are silly, I find it pretty comedic. Story's easy to follow because they don't overwhelm you with a ton of hierarchies.

But, I'd only recommend it for an on sale price as I wouldn't pay $20 for the full pack.

content:
Posted: April 9, 2015
												Got Trine 2 in a bundled special offer together with Trine and Trine 2 Goblin Menace.Trine 2 developed pretty good. The story got a little deeper, the levels became more challangeable, and the skills also developed well.A few added cutscenes support story telling. The characters got the same synchronspeakers and the scenaries and background songs are as great as in the first part. If you need a more detailed review watch my review on Trine 1 which you can find on my profile page.Trine 2 has nothing new to offer in the game universe but is a great jump and run, puzzle game combined with fighting elements and a fun multiplayer option. The Goblin Menace DLC is a great addition and worth its price. If you are a bit short on money i suggest you wait for a special offer. Its a must have for everyone who loves this genre.

												One of the best games I've played so far - not in terms of gameplay (It's simple and repetitive but still fun) - but mostly it is the charm of the game itself. The graphic effects and ambientstyle, the physics and all these small little details wrapped in a 3-man  online co-op are really a great experience. I feel like I robbed the devs when I grabbed it on the sale.FYI: Trine is ported to the new Trine 2 engine and is called "Trine - Enchanted Edition" - FREE UPDATE for everyone who already bought Trine! 												I really like this game, it is a very art filled and glorious colours. The gameplay is simple and layed back one second, very focus demanding the other. I like the easy respec system, just click reset and you can do another set up if your in any trouble of going ahead, or simply bored with the current playstyle. My favorite characters was all 3. Nice mix up and very different skillsets, you could not complete the game with neglecting one, you need all 3.You can rush thru the game in 10 hours, I did it in 14 but I was very slacking with getting every bonus item on each level.Pros:- Beautiful colours- Very nice music- Good game mechanics- Very few bugsCons:- Well none that I can think of

content:
Posted: January 20, 2016
												I adore this game.  In addition to brilliant illustration (I particularly loved bouncing on giant starfish and pumpkins), it has two levels of puzzles: the basic puzzles for each level, which vary in composition over the course of the game (unlike many games where they start to feel stale very quickly); and collecting all the experience ampules, which can be quite challenging, especially in the expansion.  There are also multiple combat difficulty levels.One note for Linux users: it doesn't play entirely nicely with the Ubuntu desktop (Unity).  Consider running it in a plain X session, or running it under Windows.

content:
Posted: July 5, 2016
												When I played Trine 1, I was in love with that game. Moving on to Trine 2, I feel I am sickly obsessed with this game. It made improvements in almost every imaginable way to an already perfect game. Characters have more diverse and interesting skills, there're a lot more secrets to uncover and the levels are ever more expansive and intriguing. And combat in general is a lot better because each character has more ways to deal with enemies.What I love Trine 2 the most is how each level feels very different from another, you have jungles, caves, deserts, snowy mountains, beaches, etc, essentially any imaginable environment you want to visit exists in this game, that great diversity combined with the game's amazingly charming visual shall guarantee one of the most pleasant experiences ever!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 23, 2016
												This game is fantastic. It's even better than the first game, and the first one was pretty great. Go see my review of that game as a starting point, then come back here. Trine 2 has pretty much all of the cool mechanics of its predecessor, but adds some really neat new ones. The visuals are even better than the first, if that's possible. There are new enemies and obstacles to overcome and some pretty cool boss fights. Almost anything that made the first game great is here plus more. The only thing I can think of missing from the first game is the items that you could find and distribute among the 3 characters to improve them. But I never felt they were that impactful anyway, so it was probably a wise choice to leave them out.  With the goblin story DLC this games has more levels than the first and has a ton of achievements to boot. You really should give this game a try.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 13, 2016
It is $3 now so why not????!!!Puzzle platformer with great co-op design and beautiful graphics. Gameplay: pretty standard puzzle platformer with some element of action, so if you are interested in this genre you will probably get exactly what you expected. No surprises, but still fun.Plot: Personally I don't think plot is that great. It is acceptable, but doesn't add much value to the gaming experience in general. Art: Graphics is fantastic - I have tons of screenshot just because it is a genuinely beautiful game. Co-op: I finished my first playthru alone and played with friends for several more. Playing alone is perfectly fine (and fun) but the co-op mode just makes it better- casual, funny, and no one feels left out.Difficulty: Platforming is not challenging at all. Some puzzle might take a while for the first time if you play alone but in general very managable (and having a few challenging puzzles is not a bad thing)Replay value: Acceptable, for collectables, achievements and new possible solutions from different skills. Also just fun to see how your friends play the game for the first time.Price: Slightly overpriced, but absolutely worth it when on sale (and it's on sale fairly often)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 18, 2016
												This must be the first game I've played(that I remember) that I've also finished on the same day I started it on(according to Steam, it took me 8 hrs to finish so that would have meant I sat next to my computer playing this game from beginning to finish for 8 hrs straight), story wise I think that might be a credits bugged becauyse it kept rolling or this game has a really long set of credits to go through...? Or it was suppose to happen and it's just a matter of how long it takes you to get bored by reading the repeated credits? hahahaha I was expecting for something at the end, like a reward for watching through the entire credits, maybe a bonus cut scene or something. All done on medium difficulty.So the story continues from Trine 1 if you've played that, with the same three characters. I didn't really dwell too much into the story, more at having fun and trying to solve them puzzles....hahahaaa At least the puzzles here aren't as fustrating as the ones in Trine 1, or maybe it was because at times I had a coop random help me out rather me trying to solo it alone...? I don't know, I might try solo this to see if there was a difference in puzzle difficulty and length...when I can be bothered of ccourse...hahaha XPGameplay wise, is pretty similar to its prequel, though you have a slightly different system to upgrade your character's abilities from the first. For some reason, Trine 2 felt more fun to play than Trine 1, maybe I started off with mutliplayer coop(instead of soloing the campaign myself) and expected/hoped randoms to come drop by - which they did at times.Graphics, yeash definitely an improvement over Trine 1 original, though there's an Enchanted version that pretty much puts it on par with this game. My settings are as follows: 1920x1080 @ 144Hz, Anti-Aliasing @ Extremem so that apparently is FXAA + 4xSSAA and I also had V-sync on, so I don't have to worry about screen tearing. Graphics detail level is on Very High and I don't have anything to play this game on stereoscopic 3D mode so I leave it on default which is Automatic.Whilst ingame, I've notice I've never actually got to 144fps mark which was a shame because it didn't make good use of my 144Hz monitor... it seems to be hovering around 60-ish(sometimes up to 70 and up to 100 duringthe non-ingame cut scenes; I believe it hasn't ever dipped below 60, ok maybe 58 or so, but it hasn't gone down any further than that), which is still good. Though, since one of my GTX 770s is practically offline(as nvidia disabled SLi for windows XP on geforce cards 600 and up - which I later found out AFTER I bought two of these bad boys for the purpose of SLi; but don't worry, my windows 7 boot will make up for it - yes it's a dual boot system, so it wasn't all for nothing! :P Actually, I believe, since this game uses PhysX, my 2nd 770 might be the dedicated PhysX card for this system so that means less load for the first card which is offloaded to the 2nd card and since the 2nds card is also the exact same 770, it should be a *perfect* match up)But yeah, they look pretty.Sound, I believe this game appears to be running surround sound(I was able to get sound from my rear right and left, my my side left and right don't appear to be working or I didn't hear anything from them because they're so soft, so this could be a 5.0 channel game or 4.0 channel game...), though I'm not sure if there's an LFE channel or if the center speaker is in use(I didn't actually test this, I just wanted to enjoy the game for what it is and not try to find something to criticize about).Yeah, I had fun, so I guess I recommend this - definitely got my money's worth from this however much I paid for this - I don't actually remember how much I bought this for, apparently got it two years ago...or at least that's what it said before I launched the game today). I did play some multiplayer coop and yes it does work, but there's like hardly any one hosting, so best bet is to start your own and hope randoms come by and play.===========================Played on "The Beast"i7-3970x, 64GB RAM, 2x GTX 770s 4GB VRAM, WinXP x64 Pro, 4x SSDs, 2x HDDs, Rampage IV Extreme, X-Fi Titanium Fatal1ty Pro, custom water loop, 2x BD-drives, TJ07-BW, 850W PSU, and many fans! Resolution: 1920x1080 @ 144Hz

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 10, 2014
Short version: 92% (73% for the DLC)Trine 2 takes a bold step and turns into a more puzzle-oriented game with a reworked and upgraded balance and ability system. Completed with larger, more detailed and even more charming levels, the game is superior to the predecessor in almost every way. Too bad the DLC couldn’t hold this level of quality.Long version:Like all sequels, Trine 2 tries to give you more of the things that made the first installment good while trying to re-balance or redo all the parts where it lacked.This of course means that the game looks even better than Trine. The levels offer more variety, they are more detailed than ever, and they are also are more challenging, forcing you to use all three characters for real this time.This also takes us to the more criticised part: whereas Trine was a traditional platformer, Trine 2 is more of a puzzle game with platforming elements. There are several parts on every level where you may need to stop and try to figure out how to proceed, and it usually involves the abilities of at least two characters. On one hand, it’s a major improvement, but on the other hand it does feel like a setback compared to the first game’s fluidity.Whereas Trine used the simplest of stories, Trine 2 tries to give you a little more complex narrative on why are you visiting the various levels. Don’t expect anything groundbreaking, though. The three main heroes also receive a makeover, giving them truly unique character traits and personalities, and their banter has improved a lot too.Sadly the game is not without faults, and these faults even have a name: the Goblin Menace DLC. Even though it gives you even more levels, all of them rely on one new gimmick: the anti-gravity arrow. You won’t find many puzzles where proceeding isn’t tied to this one ability, turning the new levels into a never-ending series of tedious trial-and-error jumps into thin air, which will wear very thin by the time you reach the floating islands. At least these new levels look even better than before, so it’s a small consolation.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 20, 2014
												This game has one of the most beautiful graphics.But the gameplay itself... It's just fine. There are some elements from Portal 2 in it, only less fun and challenging.What I particularly didn't like about this game, is that the puzzles require not that much of a brain as reaction speed.Often it's about how fast can you press the buttons or how precisely can you place objects. The game does not give you that much opportunities to enjoy your ability to solve puzzles.Compared to Trine, Trine 2 is better: both in big things like the story, the graphics and the mechanics, and in small things likethe ability to reset skill points (though, they also should have kept the floating platform skill from the first game);and the option to save the game at any point (in the first game you had to continue from the beginning of the level).Note: the DLC "Goblin Menace" is annoyingly hard, as the level design is wrapped around tight opportunity windows and precise reaction, which is quite problematic due to controls and mouse sensitivity issues.Despite all the flaws, the game is worth the money, specially with a discount. Better played in CoOp than single player mode, as some areas are insanely hard for a single player.I give it 6/10

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 10, 2014
Short version: 92% (73% for the DLC)Trine 2 takes a bold step and turns into a more puzzle-oriented game with a reworked and upgraded balance and ability system. Completed with larger, more detailed and even more charming levels, the game is superior to the predecessor in almost every way. Too bad the DLC couldn’t hold this level of quality.Long version:Like all sequels, Trine 2 tries to give you more of the things that made the first installment good while trying to re-balance or redo all the parts where it lacked.This of course means that the game looks even better than Trine. The levels offer more variety, they are more detailed than ever, and they are also are more challenging, forcing you to use all three characters for real this time.This also takes us to the more criticised part: whereas Trine was a traditional platformer, Trine 2 is more of a puzzle game with platforming elements. There are several parts on every level where you may need to stop and try to figure out how to proceed, and it usually involves the abilities of at least two characters. On one hand, it’s a major improvement, but on the other hand it does feel like a setback compared to the first game’s fluidity.Whereas Trine used the simplest of stories, Trine 2 tries to give you a little more complex narrative on why are you visiting the various levels. Don’t expect anything groundbreaking, though. The three main heroes also receive a makeover, giving them truly unique character traits and personalities, and their banter has improved a lot too.Sadly the game is not without faults, and these faults even have a name: the Goblin Menace DLC. Even though it gives you even more levels, all of them rely on one new gimmick: the anti-gravity arrow. You won’t find many puzzles where proceeding isn’t tied to this one ability, turning the new levels into a never-ending series of tedious trial-and-error jumps into thin air, which will wear very thin by the time you reach the floating islands. At least these new levels look even better than before, so it’s a small consolation.

Posted: December 13, 2015
												The concept has a potential but the game design has some flaws.Pros:+ Pretty graphics.+ Kids friendly.+ Has some puzzles in it that involve phyiscs.+ Production valuesOn the edge:? Combat is pretty simple? Thief character is limited to arrows and ropes.Cons- Reptitive puzzles solutions.- Puzzles are always about "how do I get there".- Co-Op is weak. You rarely feel that you have to work together and when you do, it just look weird and very awkward.Final recommendation:The game is not bad by all means. It looks and sounds wonderful. It might be fun for younger ages demographics. However, if you were a hardcore 2d gamer who emphasis on gameplay over production value, I'd say to give this a pass or buy it on discount.

content:
Posted: March 14, 2016
												Trine 2 is perhaps one of the most visually stunning 2D platforming games. Either playing co-op or on your own this really is a fantasy-themed 2D platformer with a difference. The game sets a new standard for puzzle driven adventures and the relatively short-length campaign has a wealth of overlaying puzzles and secrets and is an overall entertaining experience and a joy to play.Instead of the usual jump and grind gameplay of the generic platformers, Trine 2 offers a more intricate puzzles with the freedom to find various solutions. Even more interesting is when you’re playing with two or more players the game becomes a colourful array of opportunities to help each other along in an almost sandbox like environment.Switching from character to character is the only way to make any progress when playing alone in single player but invite some friends along and Trine 2 really shines through. Trine 2 features three heroes – a knight, wizard, and a thief – whom you can switch between at any point through the levels. All have their own individual strengths that they can bring to the table at any given time; this keeps the entertainment of gameplay going so you don't end up rage-quitting when getting stuck on one bit for far too long.THE GOOD- Clever platform/puzzle gameplay- Wonderful graphics with physics effects.- Brilliant sounds and speech- Excellent online co-operative playTHE BAD- Sometimes the puzzles are a bit repetitive.- No combat mode for the WizardDISASTER | BAD | MEDIOCRE | OKAY | GOOD | GREAT | AMAZING | MASTERPIECE

content:
Posted: May 30, 2015
												Trine 2 is an excellent platformer, the difficulty settings accurately reflect what you sign up for, the soundtrack is again excellent, the visuals are breathtaking - and some of the puzzles clever and fights challenging. My only gripe is the ability to refund and re-spend ability points at will. It is great for experimentation, but honestly removes any sense of figuring a clever way around some of the puzzles. For example, you often run into a puzzle that you know you could have easily solved had you spent your points on platforms instead of new arrows. Rather than work out some ingenious solution around it - you reshuffle your points into platforms - pass the puzzle, and put them back where they were.It's a small mechanical decision but it dramatically effects my investment in play. There may be a mod to fix it, but this is a review of the base game and that's my only complaint. Other than that, worth the money if you like platformers. Check out the gameplay if you're unsure - it is exactly as fun and whimsical as it looks.Only people who may NOT like this are people looking for a fun co-op experience. With the full 3 players you can not switch, so if the crucial character dies - you basically have to respawn or backtrack. It seems like a system designed to make 3 friends hate each other.Other than that - worth every penny.

content:
Posted: March 7, 2016
												Quick Summary: 2 dimensional side scrolling platformer with some combat and puzzle solving. There’s more danger than in the first Trine game, both from traps and from enemies. Co-op campaign play is available.Once again you take on the role of 3 heroes bound by the mystical Trine artifact. Instead of skeletons as enemies, this time most of the baddies are goblins, and the enemies are actually tougher in this game. Not only because they seem to have more life, but they also seem to attack unpredictably at times. Your quest for Trine 2 is defeating the Goblin Menace (and a witch) and restoring peace to the kingdom.Amadeus the wizard can conjure up boxes and planks for solving puzzles, Pontius the knight can kick goblin♥♥♥♥♥with his weapons, and Zoya the thief can shoot arrows or grapple onto wooden objects for platforming. Just like in the first Trine you only control one of the characters at any time, but you are free to instantly switch to one of the other two as the situation requires.  For example you enter a room and grapple up a ledge as the thief, then switch to the knight to kill all the critters, and finally switch to the wizard to telekinetically stack boxes on switches to exit the room. The game is pretty fast paced so this whole scenario could happen in 30 seconds.Pros:+Like the first Trine, the game as amazing graphics and art design, from the monsters to the background and particle effects. Even though the game is 2 dimensional, the incredible detail makes it feel like the background is part of the experience.+Most of the puzzles are easy enough that casual players won’t be put off. I know I get frustrated playing puzzle games, but in Trine 2 you can run past most of the game if you don’t want to be bothered collecting experience bonuses.+Unlike Trine 1, you can now reset your skill loadout at any time for free. This means you can easily change your character builds to confront specific challenges or complete specific Steam achievements. Cons: No real drawbacks.Trine 2, like the first game is something that every gamer should enjoy. If you’re looking for something to play with a casual gamer or family member, the Trine series is great for this. You’ll probably have the Complete Story edition too that includes the Goblin Menace DLC (with more difficult missions than the base game). Multiplayer coop gameplay is available and you can play with friends or strangers on Steam.

												  Primeiramente: é sensacional!  Jogando pela primeira vez você percebe o gráfico bem construido e muito bonito, uma jogabilidade simples mas que atende todas as necessidades no decorrer do jogo e personagens super legais de se jogar. Um mago, um guerreiro e uma ladra.  Mas nem tudo são flores e magia. Apesar da trama bem elaborada e piadas bem feitas o jogo é bem curto. Ao longo dele temos prêmio bem bacanas como poemas (que fazem sentido apenas em inglês) e pinturas colecionáveis muito bem desenhadas. Apesar dos tesouros, o jogo é realmente curto.  Eis que surge a surpresa do dia: COMPREM A COMPLETE STORY. Ela fará você feliz e você se divertirá com mais horas de jogo e cenários mais bonitos. Fases bem elaboradas e assim que consegue-se todas as magias dos personagens o jogo fica 100% melhor.   Resultado final: é um jogo MUITO bom e realmente vale a pena.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 16, 2015
"What is Trine 2?"Was the very first question someone asked me about Trine 2 was:And I kid you not folks, I looked at the person and tried desperately to not shout out loud "YOU DON'T KNOW TRINE 2!???" To be frank, I just calmly(I'm serious) told the person it's a 3 player co-op action/adventure/small rpg/ side scrolling platformer game in a 2.5D environment with gorgeous graphics and puzzling puzzles to test your mettle on.The sequel to Frozenbyte's earlier title Trine, Trine 2 builds upon it's predecessor foundations and game-play by flushing it all out. By means of adding even more graphical options and making the game stand out aesthetic wise to fit the side scrolling theme. The rpg skills you earn have been expanded so you can learn more than the limited amount you can spend points on in the first game. The puzzles you thought were easy in Trine 1 are perhaps significantly harder(just a little wee bit hard, depending if you can handle the mental strain) Granted it's not intensive as puzzles as the Portal franchise from Valve. Rather the puzzles are just there to halt your progress and think about in a minute or two on how to solve it. Story wise our three unfortunate(Or fortunate in finding trouble along the way) main protagonists find themselves entangled with a princess to save her kingdom from evil... BORING! Would've been your first impression of it, but it's far from a simple adventure to save a kingdom. Far from it indeed. There are documents hidden in chests scattered throughout the levels to provide further back story on the game itself. Which is invaluably precious in providing insight onto the simple task assigned above by a princess. I'll leave the rest to your imagination to see how the story will unfold... 3 Heads are better than 2? or 1?I played Trine 2 with 2 other friends of mine and had an absolute blast of a time enjoying the co-op aspect and coordinating with each other to advance to the next level. With the occasional friendly fire I accidently(sometimes) hit them with. Unintentional though! I by no means am a sadistic friend who enjoys the torment of my friends dying before me... Moving on, the options to play in co-op are a lot. you can choose to turn off friendly fire(don't turn this mode off when playing with friends to enjoy their suffering), turning off the option to lift your comrades with boxes,  or put on classic mode and stick with one character, or cheat and have the ability to choose on the fly a different character. 3 Shield-Bro's!? No problem. Let's shield our way!3 Thieves!? Lots of swinging vines here and there...3 Wizards!? Oh, the Box and Plank madness ensues!!!^ Or perhaps you young adventurers want to dabble and mix and match.2 Knights and 1 mage2 Thieves and 1 knight2 Mages and 1thief Go play with the combinations and pick whichever one suit your needs. Honestly, the game has much more appeal and replay ability if you play with a friend locally or in multiplayer, or if you're a gamer who likes playing it solo by all means do so! It depends on your play style of course. Just remember to get the most enjoyment of the experience my friend! An arrow passes through the air at deadly speed nearly nicking off her companion shield-bro's ear. Undeterred by the onslaught of arrows from the shield-bro's companion he continues on, while in passing says to the thief; "And watch where you aim those arrow!" The thief only shrugs. Shaking his head softly, he continued onwards on the path, bravely with naught a hint of fear. He charges straight into a path of goblins barring their path. Knowing such large army impedes their way the shield bro merely tells him companions..."I shall clear the way!"Sprinting his large body with a big beer belly under his armor he continues to charge straight towards the goblins......Only to find them in cages?Befuddled, the shield-bro looks in wonder at how such goblins had become entrapped in such wooden cages."Too slow, my friend," says the wizard. His ever grin plastered on his face like a devil.the ensuing cry of an angered knight echoed loudly in the valley that day...-An excerpt from the adventures of 3 friends in the world of Trine 2... Sometimes all you need are friends by your side against a perilous journey of the ages.Total Times Beaten:1Legit: 1(Played 1 full play through with 2 of my friends)Score: 9.5 /10(Score is based off how much I enjoyed the game)(Legit is based off no cheating whatsoever, no guides, walkthroughs, video’s advice, etc.)Date reviewed: 4/15/15

Lots of fun playing with others.There's no good/bad character, all three of them are equally useful on their own way.All in all,  if you seek an escape from the triple A titles, want to goof around with friends while having the time of your life, if you want to remind yourself of that essence that made you  become a gamer when Earth was still flat, this game is a must!

content:
Posted: October 31, 2012
												I already know enough to give this game a review. It is such a treat to play it. I am only about 1/4 through and am loving every minute of it. This si what playing games is supposed to feel like, yet so often doesn't. It is a magical game. It improves upon everything not done properly  in the first game. You can play multiplayer co-op, although idiots will ruin it my running through and not letting you enjoy the charm. You can pick up where u left off in multiplayer and vice versa with single player. It saves your last checkpoint so no more having to finish the level. The music is phonomenal and soothing. The art, backgrounds, lighting, and ambience are all well done. All reviews have praised the beauty of a game. The thief is now more useful with a better working grappling hook and the mage can be somewhat offensive.

content:
Posted: December 2, 2013
												Gorgeous game. Trine 2 is gorgeous game. GORGEOUS! The world is beautifully built, enemies are beautiful, environment is beautiful, lightning effects are beautiful, everything is beautiful!Other than that, it's a great game. The puzzle mechanics are engaging and fun, but most of the time not hard at all. Combat mechanics are really simple, but it doesn't matter, it's fun and it looks great. Three very different characters offer very different play styles.The game generally isn't hard, but getting all of the collectibles and all experience points is really challenging. The one minor problem this game has is the amount of bugs. There is still quite few of them. Overall it's fantastic game, I can recommend it with all my heart. And did I mention it's gorgeous?

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 5, 2014
												Back in the early 90's almost every game was a platformer, so I had quite enough of them. Nowadays, I tend to avoid platformers for that very reason.Surprisingly, Trine 2 is an exception to the rule. If you remember The Lost Vikings, then you'll see a lot of similarities between that and the Trine series. In Trine, you also get 3 different characters good for their own abilities that help you solve puzzles and progress.The knight is for fighting the goblins and breaking things. The thief is about shooting arrows and climbing places with her rope (sometimes pushing goblins into pits in the process). The wizard is about conjuring boxes and planks, building from them and levitating everything that he can get ahold of.Unlike the retro platformers, this one is heavily based on physics. This applies to rocks, conjured items and monsters. It also makes the wizard a really fun character to play as.Another distinct feature of the Trine series is the graphics. The living backgrounds are beautiful and the colors are vivid, which can make Trine look better than many AAA titles.Compared to the original Trine game, the most obvious new feature of Trine 2 is its multiplayer mode that allows up to 3 players to play simultaneously. It makes it more fun and helps solving the in-game puzzles as well as finding all the experience and secrets on every map.On top of the above, and going away from the gameplay itself, Trine 2 is packed with little bonuses here and there. It's one of the very few games that support all kinds of 3D glasses out of the box (anaglyph, passive, active). It's also properly configured to be played with a gamepad. There's full Linux and Mac OS support too. And of course it's tightly integrated with Steam, having almost 100 achievements, trading cards and storing your saved games to the cloud.

												If you like adventure games you'll love this.  First and foremost, the visuals, artwork and graphics of this game is astounding! In this side scroller game you get to play three heroes and they all have special abilities.  During the game you can switch characters at will.  The game has a mix of obstacles, goblins, bosses and lots of adventure.  I love adventure games especially when they make you feel like playing a story.  I definitely recommend this adventure game!

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 4, 2016
												Rating 9.5/10Overview: 2d PlatformerThe Good:+ An absolutely gorgeous game both artistically and technically. Every level feels alive yet without being overly distracting towards the player. + Every level has its own unique environment. In addition the level design is equally impressive, the game does a great job of slowly introducing harder and harder platforming/puzzle sections. The physics based platforming means you can find solutions that were not intended by the developers. + Good blend between puzzles, platforming and combat+ The gameplay has remained relatively the same since Trine 1. You have 3 characters that you can change at any time to utilize their skills to progress through the level. + Killing enemies or finding experience allows you to upgrade any of the three characters. + A lot of options to customize the game + Soundtrack+ The DLC is fantastic and in some regards does an even better job of changing the environments every level than the main game. The Average:Hard to find an online game, not that big of a deal since the game is probably more enjoyable single player.Some of the experience in the levels are hard to see given the lighting and backdrop of the levels.The combat is a bit dull and not as fun. Most combat can be avoided however.  Conclusion:This is one of my favorite 2d platformers on Steam and should be played by anybody who is a fan of the genre.

content:
Posted: January 18, 2014
												Trine 2 is both a game and a piece of art that is fun to play with friends or in on your own. Firstly the three characters are unique, with both extremely different interesting abilities that range from the ability to create magical objects to the use of explosive arrows and flaming swords. Then the gameplay itself, the game is a mixture of physics based puzzles that can be solved in a multitude of ways and intermittent with onslaughts of goblins and more stranger creatures. In summery, I recommend Trine 2 as an blend of a range of traditional concepts coming together in a great way, but during longer playthroughs the game can become slighlty repetitative, this however is only after extensive time and can be fixed by simply leaving the game for half an hour and then coming back with a fresh mind.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 13, 2014
												Trine 2 is one of the most beautiful and fun games I have ever played and has the best co-operative elements out of any game I have ever played and is some of the best and most fun and creative gameplay. The game has fantastic atmosphere, great level design with high amounts of detail and a fun use of physics. It's storyline is simple and a tad cliché but does have a lot of humour within it. A lot of humour also comes from co-op gameplay due to the puzzle solving required; the puzzles might I add are very fun and creative. The game has 3 characters witch the player alternates between with or without friends to get through the puzzles within the gameplay which is a great element to have, these characters are also very funny and have great story attached to them (background). Finally the game has artistic cutscenes to break up the levels which complement the game brilliantly. There aren’t really any downfalls to this game; it was a joy to play.13/15 - "Fun and creative; brilliant co-op"

												One of the best co-op games I have ever played. Good pussels, great visuals and great music. A little repetitive with the bosses though and really anyone who knows what they are doing can beat them without dying, the harder part is getting there though. I would like to mention the story a bit but when I played this with my friends we were laughing too much to bother with the story because of how much we ♥♥♥♥ed up before the cutscenes. (and just in general)I would denfenetly recommend this game to anyone. Unfortunatly I think that 8 hours of gameplay (not 100% completed and DLC included) is not worth 16,99€ so purchase this during a sale or something, also get a couple of friends and make them buy this game and play together. It's made for co-op and it knows that.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 15, 2014
												Trine 2 is a delightful change from the FPS stereotype of video games. The game is beautifully made with gorgeous lighting, and very detailed enviornments. Movements are smooth and fluid even on aging computers. There is a hint of humor here and there, along with a very simple and straight forward story. As an added plus, the online scrypt is very well written and remains smooth and glossy even on a slow internet connection. Over all, Trine 2 is a beautiful, relaxing physics platformer that is the perfectly executed and will provide about ten hours of gameplay for you and two friends (Three player co-op: Local or Online).

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 11, 2014
												Graphics/Design - 9 Sound - 7Gameplay - 6Value - 7Single Player Play Time - 7-9 hoursOverall 7.1This is easily the best looking 2D game I've seen.  It has decent sound that fits the game but nothing special otherwise.  Gameplay is the weakest facet of the game as it's very simplistic with puzzles and fighting that provide little challenge.  They should have focused more on the gameplay over graphics.  There's three main characters that each have special abilities you'll need once in awhile.  The only interesting character of the three is the wizard that allows you to build ways to manipulate the environment.  The focus of this game definitely seems to be graphics as the fighting and puzzles in the game practically seem like an after thought.  There's not much replay value other than to use the game as a graphical showpiece to friends.  It's a decent experience that makes you hope for a fully realized sequel.

content:
Posted: June 27, 2014
												Trine 2 has picturesque and bright visuals, not-quite-elaborate plot and simple but enjoyable gameplay. It's a traditional platformer full of jumping, fighting enemies, grabbing pickups, looking for carefully hidden treasures and evading various traps. Nice fairytale for kids, good time-spending and some eye relaxation for olders and elders.You have three heroes here, the commonplace set of warrior, mage, and thief; they have their own special skills, and game levels are intentionally designed to make use of all those talents. This puzzle can only be solved with mage's help, and that one is almost impossible to come through without a thief.Still, the game often allows several ways to handle an obstacle. You might choose one strategy, and it will pay out; you might choose another, and it will work for you either. It is especially evident when you compare singleplayer to multiplayer experience: a puzzle that you and your friend solved in cooperation turns out to be just as easy to crack when you are on your own.It also has some physics. This means that you can manipulate objects in different ways, making them move, jump, collide, fly, stick, slide, push, support, block, and on and on and on. This adds quite an amount of variability to the ways that you might choose to deal with a certain problem.Last words to say, Steam has acquired a good habit of providing 90% discounts for this game. Catch a good bargain, and you'll certainly have some money well spent.

content:
Posted: December 8, 2011
												Trine was one of my favourite games released in 2009. Trine 2 follows in its footsteps, having everything that made the first one great, plus full online and cross-platform co-op modes, more diverse environments & puzzles, better (more challenging) enemies/bosses and ridiculously beautiful graphics. It's a 2.5D action puzzle-platformer. In Singleplayer you can switch between 3 distinct characters and use their abilities in order to overcome enemies, traps and other environmental hazards. In multiplayer everyone controls one of the characters, which gets interesting really quick as you now need to think of a way to not only get one character across traps but 2 or even 3. Tons of secret stuff & collectibles to find, New Game+ and an optional unique game mode for MP all add to the replayability. A Collector's edition is also available and comes with the official soundtrack as well as the artbook, if you are into that kind of stuff. Highly reccommend getting this game!

content:
Posted: February 8, 2015
												A great game to play through in a day with two friends.  There isn't much to say about this game, other than you can make new friends, or ruin old ones, depending on what they do, going into this game you can play singleplayer, but don't, the only way to play this game is with two friends, and the most compitant playing the wizard.  The wizard is the most broken character, and you can basicly fly across the entire map, assuming the mediocre AI doesn't shoot you down.  The other two characters are good, but the rogue is my personal favourite, being able to swing up high then shoot then enemys below you feels great.  This game is riddled with small bugs, but if you look past the graphical glitches it's a fun game.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 27, 2014
												I think it's totally worth it. I was considering Trine (2) for a while now and I finally got into buying it by buying the Frozenbyte Collection at 80% off for just 5,99€. After 2 days, I spent 10.1 hours playing it together with my sister. Graphics/VisualsI love the graphics. They run totally fine on my rather low end machine and look amazing in my opinion. I don't think I'll need to go into detail about them since that's what the screenshots are for.ControlsMy sister was playing the game on the keyboard while I was playing it with a very old controller. The controller needed a little bit of tweaking since at first the x/y-axis of the right joystick were reversed, however this was an easy fix. Another complaint is, that using the grappling hook with a controler is a little hard, but that's about it. It played wonderfully other than that. StoryThe story was easy to follow, nothing special, though. It does what it's supposed to do, yet the story is not what the game focuses at the most. (It worth noting that I have not beaten the game, yet.)MusicThe music was amazing! Not only did it fit what you were doing perfectly, but it was also very fun to listen to. It was infact, so good that I had to go to YouTube to listen to it after I played the game. I love it. GameplayThe controls were easy to pick up (except for the few minor complaints listed above) and getting into the game was very simple. While you are playing it you need to solve puzzles in order to progress, which varied between being very easy to being hard enough to keep us thinking for tens of minutes, which I find really well done. I have to say, though, that playing together with a friend really makes some of a lot easier than playing it on your own, so they would definitely be harder when I did so. However puzzles aren't the only thing the game is made of. Often enough you'll need to fight a horde of goblins or something and combat is actually pretty neat, especially thanks to the awesome music. A gameplay element that is worth noting are the upgrades, which make solving some puzzles easier and make some boni accessible. They are not overpowered (meaning that they won't make the game too easy), yet they also don't feel like there's no difference. The only complaint I got is that I once got a bug that made me unable to buy explosive arrows because they game told me I couldn't afford them, even though I could. This wasn't game breaking in any way though, as we just went for another upgrade instead, which was worth it in the end. AtmosphereThis is where the game shines even more than in the gameplay. Thanks to the atmospheric graphics, the really well done music and well made voice acting, the game scores a high score on this one. Combat feels really nice thanks to good looking effects/animations and really nice combat music and so do the puzzles. ConclusionTotally worth it, even at full price. 9.9/10

content:
Posted: December 8, 2011
												Trine was one of my favourite games released in 2009. Trine 2 follows in its footsteps, having everything that made the first one great, plus full online and cross-platform co-op modes, more diverse environments & puzzles, better (more challenging) enemies/bosses and ridiculously beautiful graphics. It's a 2.5D action puzzle-platformer. In Singleplayer you can switch between 3 distinct characters and use their abilities in order to overcome enemies, traps and other environmental hazards. In multiplayer everyone controls one of the characters, which gets interesting really quick as you now need to think of a way to not only get one character across traps but 2 or even 3. Tons of secret stuff & collectibles to find, New Game+ and an optional unique game mode for MP all add to the replayability. A Collector's edition is also available and comes with the official soundtrack as well as the artbook, if you are into that kind of stuff. Highly reccommend getting this game!
